com.jdbwc.core

Class WCConnection

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.jdbwc.core.WCConnectionInfo
      • com.jdbwc.core.WCConnection
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.AutoCloseable, java.sql.Connection, java.sql.Wrapper

    public class WCConnection
extends WCConnectionInfo
implements Connection
    Extended JDBC-API implementation for java.sql.Connection

    NOTES:
    One of the major hurdles with communication across the Internet is latency. It causes otherwise predictable behaviour to become unpredictable. I've found through using a combination of sql transactions and stored sql procedures the latency issue can be gracefully handled.

    Transactions are one of the safest ways to ensure data doesn't go missing in transit and cannot duplicate itself in the remote database. Even better are Stored-Procedures with nested Transactions; this reduces bandwidth and increases reliability significantly.

    Ultimately it will depend on what data your application is handling and how critical the successful transmission for each portion of your code is as to what strategy your java interface and SQL queries implement.
    Version:
    2008-06-29, 2010-04-09, 2010-04-21, 2012-03-12 Updated for httpclient 4.1.3 (GA) and jre 7 compilation
    Author:
    Tim Gall (Oz-DevWorX)
    See Also:
    interface for extension method details.

      • WCConnection

        protected WCConnection()
        For the delegate only.

      • WCConnection

        protected WCConnection(java.lang.String fullJdbcUrl,
            java.lang.String hostScheme,
            java.lang.String hostDomain,
            int hostPort,
            java.lang.String hostPath,
            java.lang.String hostUser,
            java.lang.String hostPass,
            int dbType,
            java.lang.String dbName,
            java.lang.String dbUser,
            java.lang.String dbPass,
            boolean nonVerifiedSSL,
            int timeout,
            boolean debug,
            boolean dummyUA,
            java.lang.String proxyScheme,
            java.lang.String proxyDomain,
            int proxyPort)
                throws java.sql.SQLException
        Initialises a jdbc connection.
        Custom ports are fully supported in this release.
        Connection can use any valid port in the range [1-0xfffe]
        Parameters:
        fullJdbcUrl - The full jdbwc URL as passed in by the user.
        hostScheme - Host protocol scheme. Can be http or https
        hostDomain - Servers domain or IP
        hostPort - Servers port. Can be any valid port in the range [1-0xfffe]
        hostPath - Path portion of hostUrl.
        hostUser - Server username as set in the JDBWC configure.php file
        hostPass - Server password as set in the JDBWC configure.php file
        dbType - Database type. Must be one of the types in the Util class.
        dbName - Database name
        dbUser - Database username
        dbPass - Database password
        nonVerifiedSSL - If true, the driver will attempt to use unverified or self signed SSL on the server.
        timeout - Server timeout in milliseconds.
        debug - Turns debugging on or off. Its off by default
        dummyUA - Replace the HttpClient User-Agent with a built in UA that mimicks a web browser.
        proxyScheme - Proxy protocol scheme. Can be http or https
        proxyDomain - Proxy domain or IP
        proxyPort - Proxy port
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException

      • getHttpPost

        protected org.apache.http.client.methods.HttpPost getHttpPost()
        Get a HttpPost to use for communication. If the hostPort is standard 80 or 443 we use the full URL, otherwise only the URL path is used.
        This method works in unison with getHttpResponse() which uses a HttpHost for non standard ports and no proxy.
        Returns:
        a HttpPost object customised for best performance.

      • getHttpResponse

        protected org.apache.http.HttpResponse getHttpResponse(org.apache.http.client.methods.HttpPost post)
                                                throws org.apache.http.client.ClientProtocolException,
                                                       java.io.IOException
        Uses a HttpHost for non standard ports and no proxy (to increase performance).
        This method works in unison with getHttpPost() which uses a URL path for non standard ports and no proxy.
        Parameters:
        post - a HttpPost request to execute
        Returns:
        A HttpResponse from executing a HttpPost request.
        Throws:
        org.apache.http.client.ClientProtocolException
        java.io.IOException
